clinical_study.brief_title: Randomized Controlled Trial of the Impact of Mobile Phone Delivered Reminders and Travel Subsidies to Improve Childhood Immunization Coverage Rates and Timeliness in Western Kenya
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Trial of the Impact of Mobile Phone Delivered Reminders and Travel Subsidies to Improve Childhood Immunization Coverage Rates and Timeliness in Western Kenya

lead_sponsor.agency: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

collaborator.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

clinical_study.source: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

brief_summary.textblock: The project goal is to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to test whether mobile phone short message system (SMS) reminders, either with or without mobile-phone based travel subsidies will improve timeliness, coverage, and drop-out rates of routine EPI vaccines in rural western Kenya.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent of fully immunized children (FIC) by study arm
secondary_outcome.description: FIC = One dose bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG) vaccine, three doses pentavalent (diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, haemophilus influenzae type b) vaccine, three doses polio vaccine and one dose measles vaccine. The proportion of FIC infants by 10 months of age in each of the intervention arms (SMS only and SMS + subsidy) will be separately compared to the control arm using statistical analyses that adjust for the cluster design and any socio-demographic variables that may be unequally distributed across study arms

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of children vaccinated by study arm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within 2 weeks of each scheduled vaccine date
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of intervention arm infants that receive vaccination within 2 weeks of the scheduled date will be calculated for each dose of vaccine and compared to the control arm using statistical analyses that adjust for our cluster design and any socio-demographic variables that may be unequally distributed across study arms

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of children dropping out between doses
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of the differences in percentages of children vaccinated with pentavalent1 and pentavalent3 in the interventions arms compared to this difference in the control arm using statistical analyses that adjust for our cluster design and any socio-demographic variables that may be unequally distributed across study arms

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of children receiving measles and pentavalent vaccines by study arm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Age 24 weeks (pentavalent only), 10 months and age 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of vaccine coverage (pentavalent3 and measles, separately) between intervention and control arms

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion in each arm vaccinated by mobile phone ownership and by residential distance from a health facility
secondary_outcome.description: Vaccine coverage analysis stratified by mobile phone ownership and residential distance

secondary_outcome.measure: Height-for-age,to evaluate if the interventions had impact on other health status indicators
secondary_outcome.description: Using regression, average height for age in each group will be compared across study groups

secondary_outcome.measure: Direct costs for each intervention arm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 25 months, approximate time period for deploying interventions
secondary_outcome.description: Costs include SMS messages, the amount of travel subsidy transferred, and the tariffs and fees that are associated with using mobile-money. For each arm, these costs will be divided by the number of children vaccinated and comparisons will be made across study arms

secondary_outcome.measure: Bed-net usage, to evaluate if the interventions had impact on other indicators of health status
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of children using bed-nets will be compared across study groups

secondary_outcome.measure: Vitamin A coverage, o evaluate if the interventions had impact on other indicators of health status
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of children who have received vitamin A supplementation will be compared across study groups

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Mother of infant aged 0-4 weeks during the study period
2. Current resident of one of the study villages
3. Willing to sign informed consent for the study
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Plans to move out of the study area in the next 6 months
2. Resides in a village with active immunization intervention/program
3. Has already received immunizations other than birth dose of BCG or polio
